dialogs.original: Approach, Sir Andrew. Not to be abed after midnight is to be up betimes, and  diluculo surgere,  thou knowst,
dialogs.translated: Come, Sir Andrew. To be still awake after midnight is to be up early in the morning, and you surely know that waking up at dawn is supposed to be healthy

dialogs.original: Nay, my troth, I know not. But I know to be up late is to be up late.
dialogs.translated: No, truly, I don't know. But I do know that to be up late is to be up late.

dialogs.original: A false conclusion. I hate it as an unfilled can.   To be up after midnight and to go to bed then, is early, sothat to go to bed after midnight is to go to bed betimes.   Does not our life consist of the four elements?
dialogs.translated: A false conclusion. I hate your logic like I hate an empty wine goblet. To stay up past midnight means going to bed in the early morning, so therefore to stay up past midnight is to go to bed early. Doesn't life consist of the four elementsfire, water, earth, and air?

dialogs.original: Faith, so they say, but I think it rather consists of eating and drinking.
dialogs.translated: Well, that's what they say, but I think life consists of eating and drinking.

dialogs.original: Thou'rt a scholar. Let us therefore eat and drink. Marian,I say! A stoup of wine!
dialogs.translated: You're a smart man. Let us eat and drink then. Maria, I say! Bring us a big mug of wine!

dialogs.original: Here comes the fool, i' faith.
dialogs.translated: Here comes the fool, actually.

dialogs.original: How now, my hearts! Did you never see the picture of WeThree?
dialogs.translated: How's it going, my sweethearts! We are like that picture "We Three"three fools together.

dialogs.original: Welcome, ass. Now lets have a catch.
dialogs.translated: Welcome, you jackass. Now sing us a song.

dialogs.original: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast. I had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg, and so sweet a breath to sing, as the fool has.   [To th    e  FOOL   ]   In sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last night when thou spokest of Pigrogromitus, of the Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus. 'Twas very good, i' faith.   I sent thee sixpence for thy leman. Hadst it?
dialogs.translated: I swear, the fool has an excellent voice. I would give forty shillings to have legs like his and his beautiful singing voice. [To the FOOL] Truly, that was some elegant fooling last night when you spoke that astrological nonsense about Pigrogromitus, and the Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus. It was very funny, really. I sent you some money to spend on your sweetheart. Did you get it?

dialogs.original: I did impeticos thy gratillity, for Malvolios nose is no whipstock.   My lady has a white hand, and the Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.
dialogs.translated: I put your little gift in my pocket, for Malvolio can't keep his nose out of anything. My lady has lovely white hands, and ancient warriors aren't low class taverns, you know.

dialogs.original: Excellent! Why, this is the best fooling when all is done.Now, a song.
dialogs.translated: Excellent! Why, this nonsense talk is the best kind of fooling when all's said and done. Now sing us a song.

dialogs.original: [giving money to th    e  FOOL   ]  Come on. There is sixpence for you. Lets have a song.
dialogs.translated: [Giving money to the FOOL] Come on. Here's sixpence for you. Let's have a song.

dialogs.original: [giving money to the   FOOL   ]   Theres a testril of me too. If one knight give a
dialogs.translated: [Giving money to the FOOL] There's money from me too. If one knight gives a

dialogs.original: Would you have a love song or a song of good life?
dialogs.translated: Do you want a love song or a drinking song?

dialogs.original: A love song, a love song.
dialogs.translated: A love song, a love song.

dialogs.original: Ay, ay. I care not for good life.
dialogs.translated: Yes, yes. I don't care about virtuous living.

dialogs.original: [sings]    O mistress mine, where are you roaming?    O, stay and hear! Your true loves coming,    That can sing both high and low:    Trip no further, pretty sweeting.    Journeys end in lovers meeting,    Every wise mans son doth know.
dialogs.translated: [Singing]Oh my mistress, where are you roaming?Oh, stay and listen! Your true love's coming:He can sing both high and low.Travel no more, my pretty sweetheart.Journeys end when lovers meet,As every wise man's son should know.

dialogs.original: Excellent good, i' faith.
dialogs.translated: That was excellent, truly.

dialogs.original: Good, good.
dialogs.translated: Good, good.

dialogs.original: [sings]    What is love? 'Tis not hereafter.    Present mirth hath present laughter.    Whats to come is still unsure.    In delay there lies no plenty.    Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty.    Youths a stuff will not endure.
dialogs.translated: [Singing]What is love? It's not the future.Joy in the present means present laughter.What's to come is still unsure.There's no reward for wasting time.So come kiss me while you're sweet and twenty.Youthful beauty will not endure.

dialogs.original: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.
dialogs.translated: A sweet voice if I ever heard one.

dialogs.original: A contagious breath.
dialogs.translated: A catchy song.

dialogs.original: Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.
dialogs.translated: Yes, both sweet and catchy, truly.

dialogs.original: To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion. But shall we make the welkin dance indeed?   Shall we rouse the night owl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver? Shall we do that?
dialogs.translated: If we could hear with our noses, his plague-breath would be sweet indeed. But will we make the sky dance with our antics? Will we wake up the night owl and sing loud enough to make people pray? Will we?

dialogs.original: An you love me, lets do t. I am dog at a catch.
dialogs.translated: If we're friends, let's do it. I am dog at singing catches.

dialogs.original: By 'r lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.
dialogs.translated: We'll do it thensome dogs are good at playing catch.

dialogs.original: Most certain. Let our catch be Thou Knave.
dialogs.translated: Certainly. Let our catch be "You Villain."

dialogs.original: Hold thy peace, thou knave, knight? I shall be constrained in t to call thee knave, knight.
dialogs.translated: You mean "Shut your mouth, you villain," right? If we sing that then I'll have to call you a villain, knight.

dialogs.original: 'Tis not the first time I have constrained one to call meknave. Begin, Fool. It begins Hold thy peace.
dialogs.translated: It won't be the first time someone has had to call me "villain." You begin, Fool. It begins, "Shut your mouth."

dialogs.original: I shall never begin if I hold my peace.
dialogs.translated: I won't ever begin if I shut my mouth.

dialogs.original: Good, i' faith. Come, begin.
dialogs.translated: That's a good one. But come on, begin.

dialogs.original: What a caterwauling do you keep here!   If my lady have not called up her steward Malvolio and bid him turn you out of doors, never trust me.
dialogs.translated: What a racket you're making out here! My lady Olivia called up her steward Malvolio and told him to kick you out of the houseit's true.

dialogs.original: My ladys a Cataian. We are politicians, Malvolios a Peg- a-Ramsey, and    (sings) Three merry men be we.    Am notI consanguineous? Am I not of her blood? Tillyvally! Lady!   (    sings) There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady!
dialogs.translated: My lady Olivia's a trickster, we are clever plotters, Malvolio's a loose woman, and [singing] We are three merry men. Aren't we related? I'm Olivia's uncle, right? Well la-dee-da! "Lady!" [singing]There lived a man in Babylon, lady, lady!

dialogs.original: Beshrew me, the knights in admirable fooling.
dialogs.translated: My my, the knight's very good at playing the fool.

dialogs.original: Ay, he does well enough if he be disposed, and so do I too.He does it with a better grace, but I do it more natural.
dialogs.translated: Yes, he's good enough when he feels like it, and I am too. He has more experience, but it comes to me naturally.

dialogs.original: (sings) O' the twelfth day of December
dialogs.translated: [Singing] On the twelfth day of December

dialogs.original: For the love o' God, peace!
dialogs.translated: For the love of God, be quiet!

dialogs.original: My masters, are you mad? Or what are you?   Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty but to gabble like tinkers at this time of night?   Do you make an alehouse of my ladyshouse, that you squeak out your coziers' catches without any mitigation or remorse of voice?   Is there no respect of place, persons, nor time in you?
dialogs.translated: Masters, are you crazy? What's wrong with you? Have you no wit, manners, or honesty, that you're making such a racket at this time of night? Are you trying to turn my lady's house into a noisy tavern by singing these rowdy songs without bothering to lower your voices at all? Do you have no respect for people, this place, or this time of night?

dialogs.original: We did keep time, sir, in our catches. Sneck up!
dialogs.translated: We did respect the time, sir, in the beat of our songs. So go hang yourself!

dialogs.original: Sir Toby, I must be round with you.   My lady bade me tell you, that, though she harbors you as her kinsman, shes nothing allied to your disorders.   If you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors, you are welcometo the house. If not, an it would please you to take leave of her, she is very willing to bid you farewell.
dialogs.translated: Sir Toby, I must be plain with you. My lady told me to tell you that she lets you stay here because you're her relative, but she doesn't approve of your disorderly behavior. If you can start cleaning yourself up, you are welcome to stay in the house, but if not, and you would prefer to leave, then my lady would be glad to bid you farewell.

dialogs.original: (sings) Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.
dialogs.translated: [Singing] Farewell, sweetheart, since I have to go now.

dialogs.original: Nay, good Sir Toby.
dialogs.translated: No, good Sir Toby.

dialogs.original: (  sings  )  His eyes do show his days are almost done.
dialogs.translated: [Singing] His eyes do show that his life is almost over.

dialogs.original: Is t even so?
dialogs.translated: Is this really happening?

dialogs.original: (  sings  )  But I will never die.
dialogs.translated: [Singing] But I will never die.

dialogs.original: (  sings  )  Sir Toby, there you lie.
dialogs.translated: [Singing] Sir Toby, that's a lie.

dialogs.original: This is much credit to you.
dialogs.translated: This isn't helping your case.

dialogs.original: (sings) Shall I bid him go?
dialogs.translated: [Singing] Should I tell him to go?

dialogs.original: (sings) What an if you do?
dialogs.translated: [Singing] And what if you do?

dialogs.original: (sings) Shall I bid him go, and spare not?
dialogs.translated: [Singing] Should I tell him to go, and not spare his feelings?

dialogs.original: (sings) O no, no, no, no, you dare not.
dialogs.translated: [Singing] Oh no, no, no, no, don't you dare.

dialogs.original: Out o' tune, sir. You lie.   Art any more than a steward?   Dost thou think, because thou art virtuous, there shallbe no more cakes and ale?
dialogs.translated: You're out of tune, sir. You lie. [To MALVOLIO] You're nothing more than a steward. Do you think that just because you are boring and virtuous, food and wine will disappear?

dialogs.original: Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' the mouth too.
dialogs.translated: By Saint Anne, we'll have spiced ale too.

dialogs.original: Thou'rt i' the right. Go, sir, rub your chain with crumbs. A stoup of wine, Maria!
dialogs.translated: You've got the right idea. [To MALVOLIO] Go rub your steward's chain in some crumbs, sir. Maria, bring us more wine!

dialogs.original: Mistress Mary, if you prized my ladys favor at anything more than contempt, you would not give means for this uncivil rule.   She shall know of it, by this hand.
dialogs.translated: Miss Maria, if you care at all about Lady Olivia's approval, then you won't bring more wine and contribute to this boorish behavior. She'll hear about thisI'll tell her.

dialogs.original: Go shake your ears!
dialogs.translated: Go wiggle your donkey's ears.

dialogs.original: 'Twere as good a deed as to drink when a mans a-hungry,   to challenge him the field and then to break promise with him and make a fool of him.
dialogs.translated: Making a fool out of that man would be as virtuous a deed as giving wine to the thirsty. I could challenge him to a duel and then not show upthat might work.

dialogs.original: Do t, knight. Ill write thee a challenge. Or Ill deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.
dialogs.translated: Do it, knight. I'll write a letter challenging him on your behalf. Or I'll tell him your insults myself.

dialogs.original: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight. Since the youthof the counts was today with thy lady, she is much outof quiet.   For Monsieur Malvolio, let me alone with him.If I do not gull him into a nayword and make him a common recreation, do not think I have wit enough to liestraight in my bed.   I know I can do it.
dialogs.translated: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight. Ever since the Duke's young messenger visited Lady Olivia, she's been in a strange mood. And as for Mister Malvolio, let me take care of him. If I can't trick him into making a fool of himself and turn him into a big joke, then I'm not even smart enough to lie straight in my bed. I know I can do it.

dialogs.original: Possess us, possess us, tell us something of him.
dialogs.translated: Give us the facts, give us the factstell us something about him.

dialogs.original: Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of puritan.
dialogs.translated: Well, sir, sometimes he acts like a Puritanopposed to anything fun.

dialogs.original: O, if I thought that, Id beat him like a dog!
dialogs.translated: Oh, I'd beat him like a dog for that!

dialogs.original: What, for being a puritan? Thy exquisite reason, dear knight?
dialogs.translated: What, for being a Puritan? And what's your far-fetched reason for that, dear knight?

dialogs.original: I have no exquisite reason for t, but I have reason good enough.
dialogs.translated: I don't have a far-fetched reason for it, but my reason is good enough.

dialogs.original: The devil a puritan that he is, or anything constantly,but a time-pleaser;   an affectioned ass that cons state without book and utters it by great swarths;   the best persuaded of himself, so crammed, as he thinks, with excellencies, that it is his grounds of faith that all that look on him love him.   And on that vice in him will my revenge find notable cause to work.
dialogs.translated: He's not always a Puritan, though. He doesn't remain anything for long, except for a flatterer and a yes-man, an affected jackass who tries to talk like the nobility. He has such a high opinion of himself and thinks he's so crammed full of excellent qualities that he's sure everyone loves him. And that's the weakness that I'll use to get my revenge on him.

dialogs.original: What wilt thou do?
dialogs.translated: What will you do?

dialogs.original: I will drop in his way some obscure epistles of love,    wherein by the color of his beard, the shape of his leg,the manner of his gait, the expressure of his eye, forehead, and complexion, he shall find himself most feelingly personated.   I can write very like my lady yourniece: on a forgotten matter we can hardly make distinction of our hands.
dialogs.translated: I'll drop some mysterious love letters in his path. They'll describe the color of his beard, the shape of his legs, the way he walks, and the expression of his eyes, forehead, and complexionso he'll be sure that they're addressed to him. I can make my handwriting look just like your niece Lady Olivia's. Sometimes we can't tell our writing apart.

dialogs.original: Excellent! I smell a device.
dialogs.translated: Excellent! I can smell the trick.

dialogs.original: I have t in my nose too.
dialogs.translated: I smell it too.

dialogs.original: He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop, that they come from my niece, and that shes in love with him.
dialogs.translated: He'll think, based on the letters you drop, that they come from my niece, and assume that she's in love with him.

dialogs.original: My purpose is, indeed, a horse of that color.
dialogs.translated: My purpose is indeed a horse of that color, so to speak.

dialogs.original: And your horse now would make him an ass.
dialogs.translated: And your horse would now make him into a jackass.

dialogs.original: Ass, I doubt not.
dialogs.translated: Yes, you jackass.

dialogs.original: Oh, twill be admirable!
dialogs.translated: Oh, it's going to be great!

dialogs.original: Sport royal, I warrant you.   I know my physic will work with him.   I will plant you two, and let the fool make a third, where he shall find the letter. Observe his construction of it.   For this night, to bed, and dream onthe event. Farewell.
dialogs.translated: It will be royal fun, I promise you. I know my medicine will work on him. You two will hide, along with the Fool, in the place where I'll leave the letter. Then you can observe how he interprets it. But for tonight, it's time to go to bed and dream about this plan. Farewell.

dialogs.original: Good night, Penthesilea.
dialogs.translated: Good night, queen of the Amazons.

dialogs.original: Before me, shes a good wench.
dialogs.translated: She's a good wenchI swear.

dialogs.original: Shes a beagle, true-bred, and one that adores me. Whato' that?
dialogs.translated: She's a little purebred hunting hound, and she adores me. What of it?

dialogs.original: I was adored once too.
dialogs.translated: Someone once adored me, too.

dialogs.original: Lets to bed, knight. Thou hadst need send for more money.
dialogs.translated: Let's go to bed, knight. You need to send for some more money.

dialogs.original: If I cannot recover your niece, I am a foul way out.
dialogs.translated: If I don't marry your niece, then I'm going to be in horrible financial trouble.

dialogs.original: Send for money, knight. If thou hast her not i' the end, call me Cut.
dialogs.translated: Send for more money, knight. If you don't end up with her in the end, then I'm a fool.

dialogs.original: If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.
dialogs.translated: If I don't, never trust me againinterpret that how you want to.

dialogs.original: Come, come, Ill go burn some sack. 'Tis too late to goto bed now. Come, knight. Come, knight.
dialogs.translated: Come, come, I'll go warm up some sherry for us. It's too late to go to bed now. Come, knight. Come, knight.
